newsitem.title: USA: Montgomery Ward gets approval for $1 bln loan.
newsitem.headline: Montgomery Ward gets approval for $1 bln loan.

text.p: A bankruptcy judge Thursday approved $1 billion in debtor-in-possession financing for Montgomery Ward Holding Corp to allow the ratailer to keep its stores running during a reorganization.
Judge Peter Walsh said he would sign an order approving the loan after General Electric Co's GE Capital unit withdrew a restriction on the loan at the request of the retailer's creditors.
GE Capital owns 57 percent of Montgomery Ward and all of the retailer's private-label credit card.
Earlier this month, GE agreed to loan Montgomery Ward $1 billion to help it pay for inventory and to fund operations during its Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization.

GE had sought as a condition to the loan a guarantee that it could continue to operate the profitable credit card business. The retailer's private-label credit card represents 50 percent of its retail sales.

"Without a private-label credit card program in place, we would have difficulty moving forward," David Kurtz, an attorney for Montgomery Ward, said during a hearing in U.S. bankruptcy court in Delaware.
Creditors objected to the condition of the loan because they wanted time to review the credit card agreements.

The creditors, which include the retailer's banks, want to be sure the 408-store chain is not being unfarily charged by GE Capital for credit card services, thus decreasing the company's value and the payout available to them in a reorganization.
A hearing has been set for September 10 to determine whether the credit card agreements should be revised or be replaced with a new arrangements with more favorable terms.
